Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Brett Maurer of Virginia Tech to conduct a research project, entitled "Improving predictions of earthquake-induced soil liquefaction damage," during the summer of 2012 at the University of Canterbury in Christchurch, New Zealand. The host scientist is Professor Misko Cubrinovski.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the development of a reliable index for evaluating the damage potential of earthquake-induced soil liquefaction. The index is being developed from the truly unique data available from the 2010-2011 Canterbury, New Zealand earthquakes and will facilitate future liquefaction hazard evaluations around the world. Facilitated by excellent ground motion recordings, thorough soil characterization data, and detailed documentation of liquefaction induced damage, the Canterbury earthquakes present a unique opportunity to improve our understanding of the risk to the built environment from liquefaction.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Severe and widespread soil liquefaction was observed during the recent Canterbury, New Zealand, earthquakes (Sept. 2010, Feb. 2011, June 2011, and Dec. 2011 earthquakes), causing billions of dollars in damages to residential and commercial structures and to civil infrastructure. Soil liquefaction is the phenomenon whereby a saturated soil substantially loses strength and stiffness in response to earthquake ground shaking. Like many urban centers, the city of Christchurch is located near several rivers (i.e., the Waimakariri, Avon, and Heathcote rivers) and is thus built largely on alluvial deposits. These deposits are prone to liquefaction and are responsible for much of the devastation seen throughout the region. Facilitated by excellent ground motion recordings, thorough soil characterization data, and detailed documentation of liquefaction induced damage, the Canterbury earthquakes present a unique opportunity to improve our understanding of the risk to the built environment from liquefaction. This research aimed to improve predictions of soil liquefaction severity and the potential for damage to civil infrastructure.

The primary research objective was to perform a comparative analysis of liquefaction potential index (LPI) and the observed severity of ground surface manifestations. LPI attempts to predict the occurrence and severity of soil liquefaction during earthquakes and is used in urban planning and development for hazard characterization. While LPI has been used around the world to characterize liquefaction hazards, calibration of LPI to observed liquefaction severity (actual outcomes) is limited and the accuracy of the original LPI formulation is highly uncertain. Thus, the first objective of this research was to evaluate the performance of LPI in Christchurch, and ultimately to more accurately predict the occurrence and severity of soil liquefaction, responsible for tremendous damage in earthquakes worldwide. With respect to this objective, a database was created containing 1500 field tests (cone penetration tests) performed in Christchurch. These tests are used to characterize the soils and to measure liquefaction susceptibility. Each test was processed to compute liquefaction potential index (LPI) using several common methodologies and to study the sensitivity of LPI to fluctuations in ground water depth.  Liquefaction damage data was derived from high resolution satellite imagery and extensive ground reconnaissance. LPI predictions, damage observations, and prediction error maps were generated in ArcGIS to identify correlations between poor LPI predictions and soil characteristics, ground motion uncertainty, etc. Results indicate that approximately 30% of liquefaction occurrences in Christchurch were not predicted by the existing LPI model. In addition, the error in LPI predictions appears to be tied to the soil type capping or bounding a liquefiable stratum. This suggests that the depth-weighting factor inherent to LPI should be re-developed to account for soil-type in the non-liquefiable strata, which affects the severity of manifestation at the ground surface.
